title: Why do stars appear to move? - Quora

response.answer_text: As stars get fame and fortune they can afford to purchase new homes, and tend to try to get homes where they have visibility and can show of their success. As they get more established they want to have more peace and quiet life, and they move away to more secluded places. Sometime they decide to stop in the business and might move to a semi-permanent residence in areas they enjoy being themselves and/or relax. For stars in the sky the life is different, they don’t really have a choice, and think more about them as dogs on a leach, wherever the nearest neighbors move, the galaxy etc. they have to follow. Stars tend to love physics, so they prefer to stay in orbit around other stars (binary) as well as around the galaxy (they typically belong to). Now there are extreme cases where stars can be thrown out of their galaxy by getting a boost from a black hole, where they start to move away from their birth place, but this is just due to velocity, trajectory and gravity. When it comes to humans you will never see a star move any observable distance as they as so far away, and their speed (even if it’s large) is insignificant in relation to the distance (this mean it would take even the nearest stars 1000 years to move to earth if they were on a straight trajectory. So in a life time they might move much less than a fraction of the size of the moon (if you were to observe them every year). Our nearest star (other than Sol (our sun)), is about 40,000,000,000,000 km away. Using our sun as a ‘typical’ speed 72,000 km/h, we get that it would take about 64,000 years. To have the MOST apparent motion a star would have to move sideways (not towards or away) from your point of observation. Say you observe the star for 60 years it would have moved 60 x 365 x 72,000km, giving us a triangle with sides of 1.5B km (side ways movement) and distance of 40,000, which mean the angle moved is 0.002 degrees or about 1/75,000 of your visual angle. So way more than 1 pixel on a picture would represent (and hence you not able to tell if it moved or not). So stars are not moving at all in your lifetime, however the earth is, and through it’s orbit around the sun, and rotation around it’s axis, stars looks to be moving all the time, just as a room look to be moving if you spin around in circles. And finally stars (small objects that can be a toy for a kid that’s too big to lodge it in it’s throat) would move due to the child is playing with it. I bet there are other definition of stars, but these are the ones I think about that might answer your question.

In order to understand fully a few easy steps could take you to complete comprehension….A dark room with a table will do for the laboratory….Scatter some marbles on the table carefully…..Next lay a small flashlight some where in the room; in a way that causes a small star like reflection on the marble…Don’t shine the light directly on the marbles and not too close to them…You will slightly illuminate the marbles…..Then set your cellular phone up in a way that records the star lights….Your phone’s camera will represent how stars would look as they reflect into the sky….Your phone is the sky…..Now add a second larger flashlight to the room at a different angle than the first flashlight…..In a carefully darkened room you should see the marble stars flicker and move a little….Finally move the larger flashlight in a round the room without fully lighting up the marbles…You will see that the larger light causes the reflections to move…..In our universe; we have fields of particles that act as a mirror in the sky; just like the cell phone camera…..The Earth is very large and so are the neighboring planetary zones….When combined; the Earth location and the planetary zones reflect light…..The fields in our skies; capture that light show action as the moon and sun oscillate…..The thing is; science thinks that there is a third light source that’s causing the stars to appear to be so pristine in appearance; at our ocular location…….…The illumination harmonics of the universe may be doing something even more spectacular than providing a third light….The Earth for one example could be amplifying 0 point darkness….You see within an abyss like space; light can be intensified by adding darkness as well….The Earth itself would be fluctuating as a light source itself; leaving shelves of dark voids twinkling the stars…..cJT
